Award.AwardTitle: Himalayan-Arctic Exchange: Cross-Cultural and Cross-Regional Learning in Community-Based Research Methods and Experiences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This mini-workshop project, PI Henry Huntington, provides the resources for four Himalayan scholars to join their Inuit, Canadian counterparts in Nunavut to observe, gather data, and discuss the community based research projects currently underway in Clyde River, Baffin Island, Nunavut among the Inuit communities of this region. This project is part of the Arctic Social Sciences Program's faciliatation of international research collaborations on high-latitude/high-altitude cross-cultural perspectives on global climate change.

The people of the Himalayas are undergoing rapid climate change comparative to the Arctic. For example, high altitude glaciers are melting causing massive flooding and threatening future sources of water., sacred sites are being destroyed, and changes in local flora and fauna are observed. NSF has funded several community based projects among the Inuit of Clyde River, e.g., the Igliniit project- is a collaboration between geomatics engineers and the Inuit to develop an interactive, mobile, Inuktitut (local language) GPS/field computer/weather station that allows Inuit hunters to record environmental information as they hunt and travel; the Silarlirijiit project - is a collabortion between NSF scientists and local elders to better understand regional wether patterns.

By bringing together these two communities, Himalayan and Arctic, for a technological, knowledge, and scientific exchange, the mini-workshop has the potential not only to affect the way in which indigenous communties monitor and understand the changes in their regions but it also has the potential to inform our understanding of traditional knowledge systems about the environment, create new models for working with communities in high-altitude regions, and the ability to increase our understanding of the key social structural elements of how environmental change affects social-cultural processes.

This project is quite transformational - it is a first ever exchange of scientific/local knowledge between high latitude and high altidute communities and collaborating scientists on climate change. The scientific merits are quite high, the project will give insights into local culture based knowledge systems; will transfer technology between two very diverse regions - technology developed in collaborations with indigenous communities; and this exchange has the potential for scientists to gain critical insights into social structural resilience that exists regardless of local cultural knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What are the similarities and differences between high latitudes (the Arctic) and high altitudes (the Himalayas) when it comes to climate change? Both are experiencing loss of permanent ice: sea ice and permafrost in the Arctic, and glaciers in the Himalayas. Both have indigenous and other local peoples living close to the land and directly affected by environmental change. Both are among the most rapidly changing places on the planet. And both are experiencing profound cultural and social change, in addition to a changing environment.

 

Our initial goal was to bring four Nepalis to Clyde River, Nunavut, Canada, for two reasons. First, we hoped to foster discussions between the visiting Nepalis and the local Inuit about their respective experiences with environmental and social change. Second, we wanted to share some recent community-based research methods developed in the Arctic with the Nepalis, so that these methods could be put to use in the Himalayas.

 

Unfortunately, three of the four Nepalis were unable to obtain visas to travel to Canada. Dr. Rinjan Shrestha was able to make it in May 2010, and we enjoyed very productive and informative exchanges with him. His work focuses on snow leopards, and he was particularly keen to learn about documenting local observations, as this approach would strengthen his own research.

 

Recognizing that it would continue to be difficult to get visas for rural Nepalis to visit North America, we decided to use the remaining project funds (with an additional grant) to take three Inuit to Nepal. We could achieve our goals by traveling in this direction, too. In February 2012, we visited Kathmandu and the Tsum Valley, a remote valley on the Tibetan border. In Kathmandu, we had two meetings with professional researchers and conservationists at the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) office, and with the Himalayan Climate Initiative. They were particularly interested in the research being done in Canada, and are now working to develop appropriate ways to use these techniques in Nepal.

 

In Tsum, we met with many local residents, and discussed various aspects of social and environmental change in their communities. The need to interpret from Tsumba (the local language, related to Tibetan) into English and then into Inuktitut, and back again, precluded detailed conversations, but we were nonetheless able to discuss the tensions between desiring education and yet wanting youth to return to the remote communities after their schooling, the changes in rain and snow patterns, the fact that vegetables such as cauliflower can now be grown at 10,000 feet in Tsum, and other aspects of modernization and climate change.

 

The Inuit, for their part, were deeply impressed at the strength of tradition in the Tsum Valley, and at the commitment of the locals to protecting both the environment and the human use of that environment. It was a good reminder for all of us not to take things for granted.

 

The interactions we enjoyed in Nepal have given us several ideas for further comparative research and exchanges between high latitudes and high altitudes. We are continuing to discuss these with our colleagues in Nepal and elsewhere, as we develop more detailed plans for full research projects, building on our exploratory experiences under this grant.
